articles.headline: Worry About a New Wave of Layoffs
articles.snippet: America’s workers are worried about job security as the economy slips perilously close to a second recession.
articles.abstract: America’s workers are worried about job security as the economy slips perilously close to a second recession.
articles.lead_paragraph: Not again. That is the plea of many Americans fearful about their jobs as the economy falters.

articles.headline: Tax Plan to Turn Old Buildings ‘Green’ Finds Favor
articles.snippet: Businesses are planning to use a new tax arrangement to provide financing for energy efficiency upgrades with no upfront cost.
articles.abstract: Businesses are planning to use a new tax arrangement to provide financing for energy efficiency upgrades with no upfront cost.
articles.lead_paragraph: A business consortium that includes Lockheed Martin and Barclays bank plans to invest as much as $650 million over the next few years to slash the energy consumption of buildings in the Miami and Sacramento areas. It is the most ambitious effort yet to jump-start a national market for energy upgrades that many people believe could eventually be worth billions.

articles.headline: In Small Towns, Gossip Moves to the Web, and Turns Vicious
articles.snippet: As more people share gossip over the Internet rather than over coffee and eggs, anonymous, and startlingly negative, posts have provoked fights, divorce and worse.
articles.abstract: As more people share gossip over the Internet rather than over coffee and eggs, anonymous, and startlingly negative, posts have provoked fights, divorce and worse.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOUNTAIN GROVE, Mo. — In the small towns nestled throughout the Ozarks, people like to say that everybody knows everybody’s business — and if they do not, they feel free to offer an educated guess.

articles.headline: Greece Nears the Precipice, Raising Fear
articles.snippet: Economists are beginning to wonder whether a default or a more radical debt restructuring might be no worse for Greece than the miserable path it is currently on.
articles.abstract: Economists are beginning to wonder whether a default or a more radical debt restructuring might be no worse for Greece than the miserable path it is currently on.
articles.lead_paragraph: Slower economic growth throughout Europe, and probably in the United States. Huge losses by major European banks. Declining stock markets worldwide. A tightening of credit, making it harder for many borrowers to get loans.

articles.headline: 4 Insurers Will Supply Health Data
articles.snippet: Aetna, Humana, Kaiser Permanente and the UnitedHealth Group will supply information about patients’ claims to a nonprofit group.
articles.abstract: Aetna, Humana, Kaiser Permanente and the UnitedHealth Group will supply information about patients’ claims to a nonprofit group.
articles.lead_paragraph: Several major health insurers have agreed to provide their claims data on a regular basis to academic researchers, in an unusual agreement that they say will open a window onto the rising costs of health care.

articles.headline: New Fields May Propel Americas to Top of Oil Companies’ Lists
articles.snippet: New fields in the Americas are an emerging prize in the global energy market, with Western oil companies looking to exploit untapped reserves in a part of the world with greater political stability.
articles.abstract: New fields in the Americas are an emerging prize in the global energy market, with Western oil companies looking to exploit untapped reserves in a part of the world with greater political stability.
articles.lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Brazil has begun building its first nuclear submarine to protect its vast, new offshore oil discoveries. Colombia’s oil production is climbing so fast that it is closing in on Algeria’s and could hit Libya’s prewar levels in a few years. ExxonMobil is striking new deals in Argentina, which recently heralded its biggest oil discovery since the 1980s.

articles.headline: Assassination Deals Blow to Peace Process in Afghanistan
articles.snippet: A suicide bomber’s attack on Burhanuddin Rabbani, a former president and the leader of Afghanistan’s High Peace Council, may prove devastating to talks with the Taliban.
articles.abstract: A suicide bomber’s attack on Burhanuddin Rabbani, a former president and the leader of Afghanistan’s High Peace Council, may prove devastating to talks with the Taliban.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — An assassin with explosives hidden in his turban was ushered into the home of the head of Afghanistan’s peace process on Tuesday, embraced him and then exploded the bomb, killing him and dealing a potentially devastating blow to the effort to reconcile with the Taliban and end 10 years of war.
